item.title: Why Containers
item.description:
We at Uncontainer, allow you to cleanly separate what has traditionally has been dumped on a single big server (which you can still use). Everything is concise, easy-to-understand, and easily replace-able components. For example, with Docker, it’s easy to swap out your Apache container for your nginx container in a way that doesn’t affect your application because it can run fine with any of your web server containers.

We built a platform for an innovative lending platform based on Docker which abstracted out redis, elasticsearch, postgresql, ruby on rails and celery. This platform was migrated from Rackspace -> AWS within a few hours as a consequence of containerization.

item.title: Kubernetes
item.description: Kubernetes allows you to compose your complicated infrastructure as a interconnected set of containers. You can scale this from 1 to thousands of containers (all with their own complex set of dependencies). Watch how Monzo is doing this at scale in “Building a bank with Kubernetes at Monzo”

item.title: Cloud compatible!
item.description: Docker and Kubernetes are compatible with various cloud providers - including Amazon Web Services, Google Cloud and Microsoft Azure…. as well as bare metal, plain servers like Rackspace and Softlayer
